title: Leader in Renewable Energy Usage
description: In 2023, Iceland utilized alternative and nuclear energy for 89.33% of its total energy consumption, showcasing its commitment to sustainable energy sources.

title: High Electric Power Consumption Per Capita
description: With an electric power consumption of 50,082.75 kWh per capita in 2023, Iceland ranks among the highest in the world, reflecting its energy-intensive industries and high standard of living.

title: Abundant Freshwater Resources
description: In 2021, Iceland had renewable internal freshwater resources amounting to 456,351.34 cubic meters per capita, highlighting its vast natural water reserves.

title: Universal Financial Inclusion
description: As of 2021, 100% of Iceland's population aged 15 and above, including the poorest 40%, older adults, and those with secondary education or more, had accounts at financial institutions or with mobile-money-service providers.

title: Near-Universal Female Primary School Enrollment
description: In 2016, Iceland achieved a 99.37% net enrollment rate for females in primary education, reflecting its commitment to gender equality in education.

title: Perfect Male Persistence to Grade 5
description: In 2021, Iceland reported a 100% persistence rate for males reaching grade 5, indicating strong educational retention rates.

title: Lowest Agricultural Irrigation Usage
description: In 2021, only 0.0027% of Iceland's agricultural land was irrigated, showcasing the country's minimal reliance on irrigation for agriculture.

title: Minimal Carbon Emissions from Agriculture
description: Iceland's agricultural sector emitted just 0.0008 Mt CO2e in 2023, reflecting its low carbon footprint in agriculture.

title: Exceptional Pupil-Teacher Ratio in Preprimary Education
description: In 2015, Iceland had a pupil-teacher ratio of 4.77 in preprimary education, indicating a strong focus on early childhood education.

title: Low Over-Age Student Enrollment in Primary Education
description: As of 2017, only 0.034% of students in Iceland's primary schools were over-age, highlighting efficient educational progression.

title: Minimal Youth Not in Education, Employment, or Training
description: In 2023, only 2.62% of Icelandic female youth were not in education, employment, or training, reflecting strong youth engagement.

title: Low Probability of Child Mortality
description: The probability of dying among children aged 5-9 years in Iceland was just 0.2 per 1,000 in 2023, indicating excellent child health care.

title: Minimal Natural Resource Depletion
description: In 2021, Iceland's natural resources depletion was only 0.0001% of GNI, showcasing sustainable resource management.

title: Low Net Official Development Assistance Provided
description: In 2022, Iceland provided $94.38 million in net ODA, reflecting a modest contribution to global aid.

title: Negligible Chemicals in Manufacturing
description: In 2020, chemicals accounted for -0.11% of the value added in Iceland's manufacturing sector, indicating minimal chemical production.

title: Minimal Freshwater Withdrawals for Agriculture
description: In 2021, agriculture accounted for only 0.11% of Iceland's total freshwater withdrawals, highlighting efficient water use.
